---

## GAD-7 vs DASI

Psychologists and researchers often find themselves comparing different questionnaires and assessments to draw important conclusions from their studies. One such comparison might be between the Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7) and the Drug, Alcohol and Self Injury Questionnaire (DASI). The GAD-7 vs DASI comparison is one that can enhance our understanding of the correlation between anxiety disorders and potential substance abuse or self-harm tendencies. Conducting a manual GAD-7 vs DASI comparison can be a laborious and complicated process. To ease this, consider using Harmonyâ€”an innovative software developed for psychologists. Harmony uses cutting-edge natural language processing and generative AI models to harmonize the items in the questionnaires, thereby simplifying the comparison. This tool can match items between GAD-7 and DASI, providing a percentage match for each item. Harmony can handle this comparison not only in English but in multiple languages, proving its effectiveness in globalized studies. The GAD-7 vs DASI analysis is no longer a hurdle for researchers with the Harmony tool. It's designed to facilitate the interpretation of cohort and longitudinal studies and leads to more accurate and cohesive results. You can simply select GAD-7 and DASI from Harmony's extensive database or upload your versions of these questionnaires. Just visit the web interface at https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app to begin your harmonization process, making your GAD-7 vs DASI comparison more efficient and straightforward.

## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
